author: sky.cactus
content: When <@552133098075193354> says "bundle" EIP 1559 and escalator, does that just mean "release together", or does that mean "put them into a single EIP"?

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm a fan of "release together", but I'm pretty strongly against "put them into the same EIP".

author: sky.cactus
content: It is trivial to mutate the escalator EIP such that it depends on 1559, that way you keep the EIPs separate, but they can still be tested together if desired (or separately).

author: abdel.stark
content: <@!301186049323958275> The problem if we keep them separate is that we will have breaking changes twice if they are not in the same hardfork. And if they are separate and happen in the same hardfork they are mutually exclusive if we don't combine them. Both are changing the RLP structure of transactions, in a mutually exclusive way if you take them separately. Unless you accept both formats, but that would mean 2 different possible UX, which would be the worse scenario IMO. A combination of both would end up in a unique EIP right ? For example if you look at Barnabe's proposal to merge them:  https://github.com/ethereum/rig/blob/master/eip1559/combination.md#floating-escalator-started-on-basefee. Do you see a way to handle this with 2 different EIPs ? Maybe i am missing something but i don't see a way to do so.

author: sky.cactus
content: 2718 I think would solve most of that <@574864862338088960> ?

author: abdel.stark
content: Definitely. It would help a lot

author: abdel.stark
content: So you think we could have 3 types of transactions ? EIP-1559 alone - Escalator alone - Combination. We do some tests and simulation like that. Then we take a decision and we deprecate 2 of the 3 types. Something like that ?

author: abdel.stark
content: Ultimately we will accept only one of those types ? When we take a final decision, right ?

author: abdel.stark
content: Do we have wallet providers here ? And people from Web3js, Web3j,.... Would it be interested to gather their feedback ?

author: sky.cactus
content: Any of those strategies seems reasonable to me.  I like both 1559 and escalator, though I think 1559 more critically needs to be layer 1, while escalator *arguably* could be solved at layer 2 (though, that has proven incredibly difficult for reasons mentioned elsewhere).

author: sky.cactus
content: I think my preference would be that 1559 depends on 2718 and defines a new transaction type that has a `protocol_fee` & `block_producer_fee` (I always forget what they are called in the EIP, would be nice to rename them for clarity and ease of introduction of new parties).  Escalator would depend on 1559 & 2718 and introduce a new transaction type that has `protocol_fee`, `escalation_start_time`, `escalation_end_time`, `escalation_start_price`, and `escalation_end_price`.

author: sky.cactus
content: Assuming all of the above made it into the same fork, both transaction types would be valid indefinitely.  I don't see any need/reason to deprecate non-escalator transactions, and I suspect they will be fairly common and they are a bit more byte efficient on the wire.

author: barnabemonnot
content: I am not very familiar with the structure of EIPs, but it seems doable to have two separate EIPs: 1) 1559 2) floating escalator `requires 1559` (and then a third would be dan's escalator without 1559). If this helps, the floating escalator is a strict superset of 1559, since 1559 transactions can be represented in floating escalator transaction format.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@354648206510129152> The big change in 1559 is block elasticity.  The base fee is necessary to achieve that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Miners will still get paid, but their income is expected to be similar to what they make when there is no congestion (e.g., 1 nanoeth per gas).

author: sky.cactus
content: Instead of miners getting rewarded for transient congestion like they do now (gas prices go up), with 1559 miners will not be rewarded *extra* for transient congestion.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@286152635105411072> It is not free for miners to include a transaction.  More transactions in a block slows down block propagation, which increases the risk of the block being uncled, which decreases miner rewards.  This *far* outweighs the insignificant gains a miner gets by seeing ETH burned, especially since many miners don't hold ETH.

author: kiwi.eth
content: Isn't the plan for wallets to hardcode the tip and including escalator is there to prevent a standard fee auction?

author: sky.cactus
content: Escalator addresses the cases where there is increased congestion for an extended period of time, allowing people to bid during such times without having to resort to a first price auction.
